item.title: The Recent Rise of U.S. National Wealth
item.description: The latest large surge in the U.S. wealth-to-GDP ratio has dwarfed the peaks seen in the past.

item.title: A Growth-Accounting Perspective on the Post-Pandemic Economy
item.description: Real GDP has increased at a 2.8% annual rate over the past four quarters, much faster than the 2009-20 expansionary period.

item.title: Loan Evergreening: Recent Evidence from the U.S.
item.description: Banks may have incentives to keep lending to firms to avoid losses on past loans to those firms.

item.title: Inflation, Part 3: What Is the Fedâ€™s Current Goal? Has the Fed Met Its Inflation Mandate?
item.description: Despite recent inflationary pressures, the Fed has historically done a good job maintaining inflation close to 2%.

item.title: Liquidity Dries Up
item.description: The Federal Reserve has been increasing the federal funds rate, but the interest rates banks pay on deposits have stood still, leading to outflows of bank deposits and the drying up of liquidity.

item.title: The Allocation of Immigrant Talent in the United States
item.description: Immigrants account for close to 20% of the U.S. labor force, but they often do not have an easy time navigating U.S. labor markets.

item.title: Profit Shifting Through Intellectual Property
item.description: Patent data can give us insights on profit shifting due to multinationals moving intellectual property to tax havens.

item.title: Neighborhood Types and Intergenerational Mobility
item.description: Neighborhoods that differ demographically also exhibit differences in how intergenerational mobility relates to job growth.

item.title: Can Population Aging Explain Rising Healthcare Spending Across Countries?
item.description: A low-income country spends about 5.3% of its output on healthcare, while a higher-income country spends closer to 7.5% of its output on healthcare.

item.title: The Rule of Law, Firm Size, and Family Firms
item.description: Countries with a weaker rule of law tend to have more family-run firms, which tend to be small and grow slowly.

item.title: Using Beige Book Text Analysis to Measure Supply Chain Disruptions
item.description: Simple, automated text analysis can extract useful metrics about supply chain disruptions from the Beige Book.

item.title: City Segregation and the College Degree Gap
item.description: For a 0.1 increase in the dissimilarity index, the average racial gap in college attainment increases by 1.64 percentage points.

item.title: Inflation, Part 2: How Do We Construct and Choose an Index?
item.description: Both the CPI and the PCE price indexes measure the prices of consumer goods and services— but they differ in important ways.

item.title: Inflation, Part 1: What Is it, Exactly?
item.description: Inflation measures the rate of change of a price index over time.

item.title: Long-Term Trends in Gasoline Prices
item.description: Average annual CPI inflation from 1990 to 2021 was 2.4%, while average annual gasoline price inflation was 3.9%.

item.title: Does the Beige Book Reflect U.S. Employment and Inflation Trends?
item.description: Simple, automated text analysis can extract useful metrics from the Beige Book.

item.title: Neighborhood Types and Demographics
item.description: U.S. neighborhoods can be organized into five types, which have very different demographics and geographical locations.

item.title: Supply Chain Disruptions and Inflation During COVID-19
item.description: Supply chain disruptions have contributed to large increases in PPI inflation during the COVID-19 pandemic.

item.title: The Russian Invasion, Oil and Gasoline Prices, and Recession
item.description: The Russian invasion of Ukraine has substantially increased commodity prices, increasing risk to global economic activity.

item.title: Geographic Dispersion in U.S. Employment
item.description: In the U.S., 112 of more than 3,000 counties accounted for 50% of employment in 2020.

item.title: Hires and Separations During the COVID-19 Crisis by Firm Size
item.description: The negative effects of the COVID-19 crisis were larger for firms with under 50 employees, even with loans from the Paycheck Protection Program.

item.title: The Large Gap in Stock Market Participation Between Black and White Households
item.description: White households participate in the stock market far more than Black households, contributing to the large wealth gap between them.

item.title: The COVID-19 New Business Boom
item.description: Business applications increased across all sectors in the 12 months after February 2020, but the retail trade sector saw the largest increase.

item.title: Inflation and Shipping Costs
item.description: Imports that are more reliant on ocean freight have seen higher import price inflation since the start of the pandemic.

item.title: The Great Resignation vs. The Great Reallocation: Industry-Level Evidence
item.description: Some workers have experienced the Great Resignation, but others have gone through the Great Reallocation— transferring from one job to another.

item.title: School District Expenditures and Race
item.description: On average, spending per student is very similar for Black and White students, yet schools with a higher share of Black students spend less per student on instruction.

item.title: Supply Chain Disruptions During the COVID-19 Recession
item.description: A combination of demand and supply forces caused unprecedented supply chain disruptions during the COVID-19 recession and recovery.

item.title: Asset Returns and Labor Force Participation During COVID-19
item.description: One factor that may have enabled an increase in retirements during the pandemic was rising asset values during this period.
